ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- how to calculate triple integrals, vectors, fields and flux, surface integrals etc. 
- lots of partial derivations
- intuitive mathematical skills that can be used in physics-type problems later on in the course
Introductory engineering mathematics
I learned the math I needed to which was nice
I learned multivariable calculus.
Multivariable Calculus
I have gained a very solid foundation in multivariable calculus and learned the ability to apply concepts in more engineering, physics type problems.
Contentwise, I learnt about vectors and multivariable Calculus, as well as some applications in physics and engineering. I widened my knowledge on Math.
Learned the foundations of multivariable calc.
multivariable calculus and its applications in real-world scenarios
Multi variable calc maybe
I learned so much about multivariable calculus and 3d thinking.
Line integrals and visualizing 3d
How to evaluate 3D integrals, vector calculus, surface integrals. Foundations of multi variable calculus as applied to engineering and physics problems.
I developed skills to manipulate multi variable functions
The pre lecture videos were very helpful, was able to go back for a concrete understanding

I learned the basics of multivariable calculus, from vectors to partial derivatives to Green's and Stokes' Theorems. This class was also full of interesting applications of multi to places like physics, which proved very helpful to understand these topics conceptually.
What is Multivariable Calculus and how to solve engineering-related problems using multivariable calculus.
I learned how to apply concepts and theorems about 3D space in a mathematical context.
How to approach multivariable calculus and apply it to engineering concepts

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths
- very well organized content by slides 
- close to textbook which was useful for reference
- take-home quizzes and midterms 

Weaknesses
- take-home quizzes and midterms (placed a high load on final being in person)
- content is tough to understand conceptually coming from just single-variable calculus and quite fast-paced
The course is very difficult, there are a lot of concepts thrown out, but it is hard to grasp. Potentially the course could be divided into two and allow the course content to be more spaced out.

I do enjoy the pre-lecture videos of the course however having the class then just be a perfect repeat of the videos seemed very redundant. While the method and examples in the videos were very helpful, the instructor seemed to get lost trying to communicate methods as to why things worked. It seemed they were very knowledgeable just didn't know how to explain it to us. Please don't make people go to the board after we just learned the topics it is very stressful.

The course was nice as it had asynchronous lecture videos as well as in person lectures, so you could learn the material more thoroughly. However, the in person lectures were sometimes very repetitive and seemingly unhelpful.
The strength is its applicability but weakness is how we don't learn much about what context to use each concept

The pre-lecture videos were very well made and really presented the content in an excellent manner, which allowed for solid understanding of the material during the lectures. It was extremely helpful to go through problems during class time.

The p-sets were long and arduous, which made students prefer to 'drop' p-sets rather than attempt them at all. 
The pre-recorded lectures were too technical. It would be better if key concepts and equations were explained, repeated, and used in examples, instead of showing the proofs for everything.
The in-class lectures were sometimes just the same thing as the pre-recorded lectures.
Not enough example questions were done.
The class was extremely fast-paced and hard to follow.
The content was taught in an orderly fashion, but everything past double and triple integrals (line integrals and flux) was rushed quite a bit.
the pre lecture videos were helpful but we went over the same exact material in class. could be improved if class had more examples or practice problems

I enjoyed the pre recorded lectures and found them quite useful in learning the material. I wish class was less of a repetition of the pre recorded lectures and focused more on solving practice problems.
Not taught well. No reason to go to class and no in person exams
I would definitely like to see more application problems, but Prof Puri is very good at explaining the difficult concepts.
Could have been a bit more organized in terms of scheduling. But assessments were fair.
Strengths are pre recorded lectures and weakness may be lack of engagement in class

Strengths: The exams were take-home/open-note, which ensured that our actual knowledge, as opposed to our memorization skills, was tested. I also really enjoyed the pre-recorded lecture videos, which allowed me to learn at my own pace before coming to class. I also thought the problem sets were fair, and didn't take too long. Prof. Puri is an amazing professor and really systematically walks through all of the complicated topics, so definitely try to take this class with her if you can!

Weaknesses: I can't really think of any! I perhaps would've liked to do more practice problems in class, but that's a super minor thing.
Instead of learning in the videos and practicing in class, I wish we learned in class, and watched videos of practice problems.

The lecture format was not valuable to me. We were expected to watch prerecorded video lectures before our live lectures, but they were often posted very late the night before or the morning of lecture, making it impossible to reasonably engage with them. The material in the video lectures was useful, and the live lectures were not. No material was actually covered in the live lectures, making them often times feel pointless to attend.

Strengths: the course was straightforward and followed clearly with the textbook

Weaknesses: at times it felt like the content was rushed

Strengths - open notebook final, take-home midterms, no work besides weekly (and very time-consuming) psets, supposedly easier than math 120. (note I've heard in the past midterms were in-person so maybe it was different spring 22)
Weaknesses - not that engaging (I personally don't like math but need it for my major).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to become an engineer. You learn super useful skills and calculation methods, which are quite theoretical at the beginning but gradually become more applied to concepts like electric and magnetic fields.
No, they would only take it if it were a requirement
I would recommend the class only if they needed to take this level and if the person was able to have access to outside resources, someone who asks a lot of questions in class would not do well.
yes, it was an easier math course and more supportive than a normal math course since there was only one section and less students per professor.
I would definitely recommend this course for students pursuing engineering or mathematics, as it is really a foundational course that is well taught.
Only if they need to learn multivariable calculus and haven't learned it before. It is not an easy course.
If you need this class or are interested in multi, take it. Should be able to get a good grade if you do the work.
if you need to take multivariable for a prereq, I recommend shopping both ENAS 151 and MATH 120. your experience honestly depends on the professor
This course may fit some, but does not require as much engagement with the material as MATH 120.
Not really find a different professor
Yes! The organization is so much better than MATH 120.

Yes if you can remain engaged in course. The lectures were posted beforehand so it was easy to feel like you didnt need to go to class but I got a lot more out of the class by actually attending lecture
I would, I like the problem sets as homework and I believe the course is taught well

I would definitely recommend this class! At least how the course was structured now made it very conducive to learning and not super stressful. It's a relatively smooth way to get your multivariable calculus credit, and it really makes you recognize the beauty of math in the first place!
I found our professor to be quite disorganized in class, so probably not.
Yes, I believe it was valuable material to learn as an engineering student. However, the instruction was poor and I had to teach myself the material while completing each problem set.
Only if you need it for your major or really love math. If you're deciding between ENAS 151 and MATH 120, I would highly recommend 151.
Recommended over math 120.
